CHAPTER 37: THE SIEGE OF ALHAMA

Date: April 21, 1432 (Late Afternoon)
Location: Siege Camp Outside Alhama de Granada

The thunder of the bombards had settled into a steady, methodical rhythm. Every hour or so, another stone ball would arc through the air and crash against Alhama's western wall. Dust rose with each impact, drifting across the gorge in lazy clouds before dispersing in the mountain breeze.

Juan stood on a slight rise overlooking the siege works, watching the fifth shot of the afternoon slam home. The wall shuddered. Small chips of masonry fell away. The damage was incremental but relentless—this was the patient work of artillery, measured in days and weeks rather than hours.

Pietro Calabrese approached from the gun positions, wiping powder residue from his hands. "Your Majesty. The first day proceeds well. All five guns performing properly. We've fired twenty-three shots since this morning—good pace without overheating the barrels. The western wall is taking the impacts cleanly. No complications yet."

Behind them, the camp sprawled across the valley floor. Fifteen thousand eight hundred men at various tasks—digging entrenchments, setting up supply stations, tending horses, cooking meals. The professional hum of a siege establishing itself.

Don Álvaro de Luna stood nearby, reviewing supply reports with one of the quartermasters. He finished his conversation and joined Juan and Pietro. "The siege is well-established. Supplies flowing smoothly from Íllora. No sign of relief forces or interference. Granada either cannot or will not contest us here."

He paused, glancing toward the fortress walls. "Different from Íllora, isn't it? At Íllora, Commander Hamza was defiant—pride and honor keeping him on those walls. Here..." He shook his head slightly. "Those men inside know exactly what's happening. They just can't act on it."

THE BOMBARDMENT OF ALHAMA - DAYS 1-10

April 21-30, 1432

The siege of Alhama unfolded with the kind of professional precision that comes from experience and favorable circumstances. The weather held clear and mild—spring mountain air without the storms that had plagued Málaga or the oppressive heat of summer campaigns. Pietro's gun crews, veterans now of multiple sieges, worked with smooth efficiency. Load, aim, fire, swab, repeat. Six to eight shots per gun per day, every shot counted and recorded.

By the third day, visible progress showed on the western wall. The mortar between stones began to crumble under repeated impacts. Pietro identified his target zone—a section about thirty feet wide where the wall showed subtle signs of settlement, perhaps from decades of mountain weather and minor earthquakes. He concentrated three guns on this weakness while the other two bombards kept up harassing fire elsewhere to prevent defenders from focusing all their repair efforts in one place.

The garrison tried. Every night, work parties emerged with torches to patch the damage—stuffing rubble into gaps, applying fresh mortar, shoring up weakened sections with timber. But the mathematics were against them. Each day's bombardment undid more than each night's repairs could restore. The cracks spread. The wall face began to bow slightly inward.

On the morning of May 1st—the tenth day of bombardment—something changed. Pietro noticed it first as he sighted the morning's opening shot: the target section was visibly different from the evening before, showing deeper stress fractures radiating from the impact points. "Today," he told Juan quietly. "Today or tomorrow, that section comes down."

He was right. The afternoon bombardment—the forty-seventh shot of the day—struck the weakened section with a sound different from all the others. Not the usual crack of stone on stone, but a deeper, groaning rumble. For a moment nothing happened. Then the entire section—thirty feet wide, twenty feet high—slumped forward like a tired man sitting down. Stones tumbled. Dust billowed. When it cleared, a breach gaped in the wall: not yet assault-ready, with rubble piled high at the base, but unmistakably a major structural failure.

From the Castilian lines, a cheer erupted. From Alhama's walls, visible dismay. Officers could be seen gathering, pointing, arguing. The garrison had known this moment was coming—but knowing and witnessing are different things.

Pietro approached Juan with satisfaction evident in his weathered face. "Ten days to first breach. Better than I projected, Your Majesty. The section came down clean—good rubble pile, minimal debris spread. Another three to four days of concentrated fire to widen it and create proper assault ramps, and we'll have an opening your infantry can use. Call it May 4th or 5th for assault readiness."

Don Álvaro added his assessment: "The garrison saw that collapse. They know what it means. We might see negotiators before we need to assault." He paused, watching the walls. "Or they might fight anyway, for their families' sake. Hard to say. But that breach broke something inside those walls—you could see it in how the officers reacted."

The siege camp that evening buzzed with the energy of visible progress. Morale was high. Casualties remained minimal—only a handful of wounded from minor skirmishes and accidents. Everything proceeding according to plan, even better than plan.

MARTÍN'S APPROACH - MAY 1ST, AFTERNOON

Commander Martín ibn Ahmad rode toward Alhama's gates in the late afternoon light, a white banner streaming above him. Two heralds accompanied him, unarmed and clearly visible. The rubble from the morning's collapse still smoked faintly where dust had yet to settle.

He stopped fifty yards from the walls and called out in Arabic, his voice carrying clearly: "I am Commander Martín ibn Ahmad, formerly Yusuf ibn Rashid of Granada, now in service to King Juan of Castile. I come under flag of truce with a message from His Majesty."

There was movement on the walls. Officers gathering. A brief consultation. Then a voice called back: "We see you, Commander Martín. We remember your name from the old days. Speak your message."

"His Majesty the King asks if you are ready to negotiate terms of surrender. He saw the breach fall this morning. He knows you have resisted with honor—ten days of bombardment, walls broken despite your best efforts. He offers you the dignity of negotiation rather than forcing you to wait for the assault. If you wish to talk, he will meet with your officers tomorrow at dawn under flag of truce. If you are not yet ready, he understands—the bombardment will continue until you are."

Silence. Martín could see the officers conferring urgently. One pointed at the breach. Another gestured emphatically. A third seemed to be speaking rapidly, making some argument. The discussion lasted several minutes.

Finally, the lead officer called down: "Commander Martín, tell His Majesty we will send our response within the hour. We must... consult among ourselves. But tell him we heard his offer. And we appreciate his mercy in making it."

Martín bowed from his saddle and rode back to the Castilian lines.

THE GARRISON'S RESPONSE - EVENING

Less than an hour later, three officers emerged from Alhama's gates under their own white flag. They approached the Castilian forward positions cautiously, stopping at the designated neutral ground.

Don Álvaro met them with Martín as translator. The lead officer—the same commander who had wept over his eight-year-old son ten days earlier—spoke with visible relief tempered by lingering anxiety:

"We request formal parley with His Majesty tomorrow morning at dawn. We are prepared to discuss terms of surrender. The breach..." He glanced back at the broken wall. "The breach makes our position clear to anyone who might judge us. We have resisted as soldiers should resist. We held these walls for ten days against your bombards. No one can say we yielded easily."

The second officer added: "If the terms His Majesty offers are acceptable—the same terms offered before—we are prepared to open these gates within two days. We need time to explain to our men, to organize the departure of those who wish to leave, to arrange the formalities. But we are ready to conclude this."

The third officer, younger, spoke quietly: "We fought with honor. Now we must live with honor. The breach ends this siege. There is no shame in surrendering to the inevitable."

The first officer looked directly at Álvaro: "Please convey to His Majesty: we are grateful he offered terms before forcing the assault. Many lives will be saved tomorrow because of his mercy today. We will meet him at dawn with our decision, but... we believe we can reach agreement."

They bowed formally and returned to their fortress as darkness fell.

Álvaro delivered the message with barely concealed satisfaction. "They're ready. Not just willing—eager. The breach broke their resolve exactly as it should. They want to negotiate tomorrow at dawn and are prepared to surrender within two days if terms are acceptable."

Pietro, standing nearby reviewing his gun logs, nodded approvingly. "Ten days. Breach on schedule. Surrender before assault. This is how sieges should go when both sides act with sense."

Infante Juan, who had been listening quietly, observed: "Different from Íllora. There, Commander Hamza's pride trapped him. Here, these men's families trapped them—but the breach gave them the excuse they needed. They can tell Granada: 'We held ten days, the wall broke, we had no choice.' It protects them."

Álvaro looked at Juan. "Your Majesty, what terms do you wish to offer tomorrow? The same as before—safe conduct, choice to stay or leave, protections for those who remain? Or do you wish to adjust anything given their willingness?"

The camp settled into evening quiet around them. Somewhere in Alhama, 350 men prepared for tomorrow's negotiation—the end of their siege, one way or another.

EVENING PRAYERS - MAY 1ST

In his tent that evening, Juan knelt before the small traveling altar Fray Hernando had set up. A simple wooden cross, a candle, Isabel's blue ribbon tied around the base. The camp sounds filtered through the canvas—men talking quietly, horses shifting, the distant clang of a smith's hammer.

He prayed for the men inside those walls. For the officer with the eight-year-old son. For the families held hostage in Granada. For wisdom tomorrow, that the negotiations might end this siege without more blood. For Isabel and their child, far away in Toledo. For the strength to be both merciful and just.

Lord, let tomorrow bring peace. Let these men find safety. Let their surrender be honorable. And let their families, somehow, be spared the Sultan's wrath.

He touched the ribbon gently before rising. Tomorrow would bring an end to this—one way or another.

THE PARLEY - MAY 2ND, DAWN

The sun had barely crested the eastern mountains when Juan rode to the designated meeting ground between the siege lines and Alhama's walls. He brought Álvaro, Martín, and Fray Hernando. A white banner hung limply in the still morning air.

From Alhama's gates, four officers emerged. The same three from yesterday evening, plus their garrison commander—a grizzled veteran Juan recognized from the negotiations ten days ago. They walked with dignity despite their circumstances, shoulders back, weapons at their sides but clearly ceremonial rather than threatening.

The two parties met in the middle ground. Juan dismounted out of respect, as he had before.

The garrison commander bowed. "Your Majesty. We come to discuss terms of surrender. The breach in our walls makes our position clear. We have resisted for ten days. We can resist no longer with honor."

The officer with the young son added quietly: "We pray the terms Your Majesty offers are those spoken of ten days ago. Safe conduct for those who wish to leave. Protection for those who choose to remain. No forced conversions. Freedom to practice our faith."

Juan spoke clearly: "The terms I offered then are the terms I offer now. Nothing has changed except the state of your walls. You have fought honorably. You will be treated honorably."

He gestured to Fray Hernando, who stepped forward with a written document—the same terms framework used at Moclín, adapted for Alhama. Martín translated as Fray Hernando read:

Terms of Surrender for Alhama de Granada:

Garrison may depart with personal arms and dignity, escorted safely to Granada territory

Alternatively, garrison members may remain under Castilian rule with full protections

Civilians may choose freely to leave or stay

Those who remain: protection of life, property, and Islamic religious practice

Private prayer spaces permitted (not the main mosque, per papal requirements)

No forced conversions under penalty of papal prohibition

Prisoners taken to Antequera with other captured garrisons, released when crusade concludes

Surrender to occur within 48 hours

The officers listened intently as Martín translated. When he finished, they conferred quietly in Arabic for several minutes. Juan waited patiently, watching their faces—relief, anxiety, careful calculation, and finally... acceptance.

The garrison commander turned back to Juan: "Your Majesty, we accept these terms. We will need today and tomorrow to organize—to explain to our men, to allow those who wish to leave to prepare, to arrange proper turnover of the fortress. We propose: today and tomorrow for preparations, gates open at dawn on May 4th. Is this acceptable?"

Juan nodded. "It is acceptable. You have my word: these terms will be honored exactly as written."

The officer with the eight-year-old son spoke, his voice thick: "Your Majesty... when we return to Granada, when the Sultan asks why we surrendered... we will tell him your bombards broke our walls. That we resisted ten days. That we had no choice." He paused. "We pray this protects our families. We do not know if it will. But we pray."

Juan met his eyes. "I pray the same. You are not surrendering out of cowardice or betrayal. You are surrendering because the wall broke and further resistance would be murder, not defense. Any honest soldier understands this."

The commander bowed deeply. "Then we have an agreement. May 4th at dawn, the gates of Alhama open to Castile. God's will be done."

"God's will be done," Juan repeated.

The officers returned to their fortress. Juan mounted and rode back to camp, where Álvaro waited with barely concealed triumph.

"Two weeks total," Álvaro said quietly. "Ten days of bombardment, two days of negotiation, two days of transition. Alhama falls with minimal casualties, garrison treated with honor, and we march on Granada city from a position of total strength. Your Majesty, this is how crusades should be conducted."

THE NEXT TWO DAYS - MAY 2-3

The fortress prepared for transition. Inside Alhama, the garrison organized itself—some choosing to leave for Granada, others deciding to remain under Castilian rule. Arguments could be heard through the walls as families debated their futures. Packing, farewells, practical arrangements.

In the Castilian camp, preparations continued. A garrison force was selected—150 men under a reliable commander. Supplies were organized for the transition. Fray Sebastián, who had remained at Moclín as witness, sent word he would come to Alhama as well to help establish the same protections.

On the evening of May 3rd, Juan stood looking at the fortress. Tomorrow those gates would open. Another fortress secured. Another step closer to Granada city itself.

Supply caravans can still move through if they're willing to risk guerrilla-style travel."
